div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for [PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week for SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond JEDDAH but call at TOR (for SINAI) EL WEDJ and YAMBO as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: GERMANY'S BETE NOIRE.
div.p: A frank statement of the views of the merchant princes of Germany respecting the foreign policy of their country would certainly be of great interest and importance not only for France, but for England. M. Henri de Noussanne, of the "Echo de Paris," who is now making a tour through Northern Europe and Scandinavia, gives particulars of such a statement made to him at Hamburg by a "personage who has great interests involved in German maritime affairs, and who is not unknown to the Emperor William II, and his principal collaborators, nor to several notabilities of the French commercial and financial world." It is of interest, says the "Times" Paris correspondent, as a fresh manifestation of the desire of Germany to detach France from England and to secure her own hegemony, at least in the economic sphere.

This Hamburg shipping magnate, who regards politics as a matter of business, desired to speak plainly as a business man. Referring to the manner in which Germany has treated France for the past 36 years, he said that she had naturally taken advantage of the situation which she created, and would continue to do so. The Germans did not, however, propose to carry out their national programme by war. As to the Pan- Germans, every country had its Chauvinists. The programme of the business men was to live in peace, to produce a large quantity at merchandise, and to be strong enough to trade freely everywhere. In reply to the objection that the economic struggle and the excessive growth of population necessarily led to conflicts, and to a reminder as to the Kaiser's speeches, the Hamburg magnate said "We regard our Emperor as our best commercial traveller. In reality he has no more desire for war than I have. All our money is invested in business. All our credits are inextricably bound up together. We lack reserves. If a war were to break out between Germany and England, 50 per cent. of the Hamburg Arms would suspend payment within 34 hours." To the objection that such considerations would not weigh with the military party, the reply was that the latter was the servant and not the master of the country.

As to the possibility that a conflict might occur independently of the will of Germany, this German authority said : - "In any case, it is not France that we have in view. All she has to do is to keep quiet. We do not under- stand how she can play the game of England. After all, it is not so long since Fashoda."

In reply to the retort that the Rhine was, after all, nearer than the Sudan, the Hamburg shipping magnate turned the conversation to France's neglect at her naval and maritime interests. Frenchmen, he said, should not reproach Germany with having profited by their own neglect The Germans devoted themselves to trade, while the French preferred banking. "So be It," he added, "but let each of us under stand our parts and not quarrel. Let us, on the contrary, come to an understanding

Being reminded that something more than (air words was required for an understanding, particularly after a threat of war had been followed by the Emperor's visit to Tangier, the German merchant exclaimed —"Tangier ! always Tangier! But how can you pretend to prevent us from seeking a position in the Mediterranean when we send on an average every year 250 ships and a million tons of goods more than you yourselves through the Suez Canal, which is nevertheless within a stone's throw of Marseilles. He added that the Germans did not seek to conquer, but merely to assure freedom for their trade. He repeated a statement made by the Kaiser recently in presence of Herr Ballin, director of the Hamburg American Line, and himself respecting France: "A country which has the finest coasts in Europe and not a single free port, a navy and no merchant, marine, colonies and no colonists or emigrants other than officials, and who yet remains indifferent to this state of affairs is abandoned by God, as He must have stricken it with blindness if it does not recognise that it is on the way to ruin." This was repeated by the Hamburg magnate, not in order to offend his French hearer, but merely to show him that the future at France, like that of Germany, was on the sea, and that if France, like Belgium, had marched hand in hand with the German Empire her present condition would be more calm and prosperous and her fortune more secure. As it is, France, he said, has not sufficient soldiers or valuable alliances to defend a treasure which might be destroyed in a moment by a victorious enemy who would impose an indemnity at war.

M. de Noussanne gives the moral of the whole interview in a saying which he affirms is current in private among German diplomatists —"the peace of the world can only be secured at the cost of England."

div.head: The Mahmai.
div.p: The Fourth Infantry Battalion will provide the escort for the Mahmai.

div.head: H.H.S. Aida
div.p: Our correspondent reports that H.H.S. Aida entered the Canal at 10 o'clock yesterday moring bound for Alexandria.
Comptoir Financier
We understand that the London organisation of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypt will begin working on the 1st proxo.
Drowned In the Canal.
A native child's body was fished out of the Mahmoudieh Canal on Thursday afternoon The child had evidently met his death by tumbling over the bank.
Cruesome Discovery

Yesterday the dead body of a native, in a highly advanced state of putrefaction, was discovered in a pit by the Hilmieh Bridge Alexandria. The post mortem examination showed that death was due to natural causes.
Mouled Abd II Rahim

News comes from Keneh that the Mouled of Sheikh Abd el Rahim El Kinawi was held during the last two days at that town, which has been crowded by a large number of people coming from the neighbouring villages to attend the ceremony.
Shooting Accident

Yesterday a native official in the service of the Government Railway stores was run over by a train at El Farz in the Moharrem Bey quarter of Alexandrie, and had both his feet and his right hand cut off. He died while being taken to hospital.
Farewell to the K.R.R.

A farewell smoking concert to the 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps will be held at the Soldier's Club, Cairo, this evening. Previous to the smoking concert there will bea friendly billiard match between teams of the 1st K.R.R Corps, who were winners of the last team tournament, and the Royal Engineers.
The Brindisi Mall

The mail bags for despatch by the P. and 0 Port Said Brindisi steamer will be made up at 3.10 p.m. to-morrow, not on Monday, as notified in our issue of yesterday. Similarly letters most be registered by 2.1O p.m. on that to day , and money orders and insured articles must be handed in by noon to-morrow, and parcels by six o'cloek this evening.
The Mahmoudieh Tragedy

The Alexandria Parquet is investigating the circumstances attending the murder of the young native girl, whose corpse was discovered in the Mahmoudieh Canal near Ramleh last Wednesday. From a cross tattooed on her wrist the girl is believed to have been of Cop tie origin. The post mortem examination showed that the body had been for some time in the water and evidently came from some distance. No clue to the victim's identity has as yet been found.
The Plenary Commission.

The monthly meeting of the Alexandria Plenary Commission, which was to have been held lest Wednesday, has been put off until Wednesday next, as there were not sufficient members to form a quorum. There is no important business, however, for discussion. The chief subject for discussion, besides some credits, are the abuse of cycles, using hooters and the question of enforcing the use of a covering for carts conveying lime and such like dusty materials through the public streets.
Old Fayoum Willia.

The official correspondence in Messrs Grenfell Hunt's new work on the Hibeh Papyri offers new light on many points interest, especially as regards the Fayoum. It has been doubted, ever since the publication of the wills of the military landholders of the Fayoum is the Petris papyri, whether the owners had any right of leaving their land by will to their heirs. It new appears that upon the death of any landholder of this kind (cleruoh) the State resumed his land into the Basilikon or Crown property. The curious point is that the lot kept the name of its former owner, and was known by it permanently. This recalls the three sections of the Fayoum which were permanently known by the names of three men, probably their first governors -Herselides,Polemo, and Themistes.
"The Cult of a Foreign Race."

As Mr Wilfrid Bloat has again come before the Egyptian public, it is worth while recalling a passage in Mr Edward Dlcey's "The Story of the Khedivate," which contains some very pointed remarks about that gentleman "When" he says, "our countrymen go in for what I may call the 'cult' of a foreign race or creed, they always remind one of the amateur who, when he acted the Moor of Venice, thought it necessary to black himself all over, from the soles of his feet to the tip of his forehead. I could never take Mr. Blunt's Orientalist seriously, after I found out that, in order to sustain his character as a denizen of the East, he used, en arrival at Cairo, to be met at the station by his camel,and ride to Shepherd's Hotel, a distance of barely five minutes' walk, sooner than take a carriage like a commonplace tourist."
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other services. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt Address, Secretary, British Chamber Of Commerce, Alexandria [Advt.]

div.head: THE SIRDAR'S DEPARTURE.
div.p: INTERVIEW AT BALMORAL
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday afternoon.

His Excellency Sir F. Reginald Wingate Pasha, Sirdar, is leaving London to-day for Egypt. On Wednesday he was summoned to Balmoral, where the King and Queen are now staying, by special command of the King, with whom be had a lengthy audience.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS
div.p: MR. BLUNT'S PAMPHLET.
"Al Mokattam" writes a propos of Mr. Blunt's latest critique.

As we have already stated, our opinion on Mr. Blunt's latest work absolutely agrees with that of our eminent confrere— Mr. Moberly Bell of the "Times." We own only repeat with him that Mr. Blunt can only succeed in encouraging disturbance and disunion.

On the other hand we are glad to state that the number of those carried off their feet by Mr Blunt's fallacies is extremely small, but their pens are dipped in gall, their tongues are ready, and none are better posted in the art of impressing the imagination of the public by the ingenious employment of appeals to patriotism and religion. Sooner or later England will be compelled to put a forcible end to a liberty that is become intolerable unless the wiser element- of the population can stop the mouths of these frenzied patriots. We must therefore grasp the full significance of the almost official warnings of the "Times" and of the fact that British policy is unlikely to be influenced by the excited utterances of a few Liberal cranks, among whom we reckon Mr. Blunt. Finally we must realise once for all that our adhesion to a policy of attacks against England can only be prejudicial to the interests of the whole nation, and that pacific claims patiently and temperately urged can alone bring about those reforms that can be reasonably granted.

div.head: RETURNING FROM THE YEMEN
div.p: Suez, Friday.

The Turkish turkish transports Resni Olum, Mecca, and Chark arrived at Suez last night from Hodeidah and are lying at anchor in the Suez roads as usual, until necessary funds for payment of the Canal dues are procured. Two of these Transports are overcrowded with mostly sick and wounded soldiers from Arabia. The Resni Olum is one of the latest ships the Turkish Government bought from the Union Castle Line.

div.head: THE SYRIAN CONVICTS.
div.p: Among the convicts, solders and others, conveyed by the Assyr were two members of the family of the Bedr Khan who were accompanied on their way to exile by their wives and children. It is not known whether these prisoners took any part in the assassination of Redvan Pasha, but even if they were guilty, their fate,—a long and lovely exile in the Tehama or in some inland desert- must compel the sympathy even of the strongest supporters of Abdel Hamid's Government.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: Mr Chatawey, Administrator of the Alexandria Municipality. In arriving at Alexandria from Europe on the 10th October, His arrival, it is hoped, will infuse new life and energy into the Municipality, which has been in an utterly comatose state during the summer months. Some creatures sleep during the cold weather, and the term "hibernation" has been coined to express this reformative state. But with car Municipality the reverse seems to be the case, and the six hot months seem to lead to a similar state of perpetual somnolence.

The question as to who is to be chief engineer of the Alexandria Municipality is a matter of great importance to the city, and it will shortly have to be decided. The Municipality sent to the chief cities of Europe asking that men with special qualifications should be recommended for the post of chief engineer. Berlin answered that it knew of none suitable but Paris and London have mentioned suitable candidates. Although the name of Mr. Lloyd-Davis, the nominee of the London County Council, was mentioned at the last meeting of the Municipal Delegation ,nothing will be decided until next November, when the claims of the different candidates will be decided.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI SATISFACTORY AGREEMENT.
div.p: London, Friday afternoon.

At the meeting of the Board of Directors of Walker and Meimarachi Limited, which has just been held in London, the difficulties, which have recently arisen between the Managing Director, Mr. Constantire Meimarachi, and the Board, were satisfactorily settled in the beet interests of Mr. Meimarachi and the shareholders.

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT.
div.p: A Parisian contemporary remarks as follows upon the meeting of King Edward and the Kaiser at Kronberg; —

"Nous apprenons de source absolument afire, et notre information ne sera pas d Am an tie, qu'une des principales causes de la rencontre a Kronberg du roi Edouard VII et de l'empereur Guillaame II, qui a tant intrigue le monde politique, ces derniers tempo, etait une demands d'explication de l'oncle a son neveu, an sujet des troubles qui ont en lien en Egypte, an mois de Juin dernier, et qui ont es poor consequence une attaque brutals contre des officiers anglais, dont l'un des memes est mort a la suite de ses blessures. Or, il paraltrait que le War Office a en mains la preuve indeniable que les dits troubles ont été fomentes par des agents allemands, a la solde du gouvernement allemand, et oe sont ces preuves indiscutables que le roi Edouard VII voulait, pour le contender, mettre sous les yeux de son imperialnevue."

div.head: THE LABBANE AFFAIR.
div.p: The enquiry, heLd by the Alexandria Parquet and Police into the tragic death of Osman Ahmed yesterday week in the Labbene Caracol has been terminated. The finding of the court of enquiry has not yet been made public, but we are in a position to state that the charge of manslaughter against the iacriminated policeman has not been sustained by the evidence adduced.

div.head: A "SUCRERIES" CASE.
div.p: An echo of the liquidation of the "Sucreries" company will come before the Cairo Mixed Courts on the 29th prox. The plaintiff is a former shareholder, Mr Daniel Bienvenu, and he is bringing an action against the administration and auditors of the Sucreries Company for the loss amounting to frs. 17,275, which he suffered in the liquidation of one hundred shares.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO
div.p: All the elite of Alexandria society were present at the cotillion hall held on Thursday evening at San Stefano under the auspicion of the Club. The handsome hall of the Casino was beautifully decorated and lighted. The cotillion was a huge success, thanks to the untiring efforts of Mr. Adolphe Bagdalli, the organizer of the Club, fetes, and he was ably assisted in his labour by the mesdames Barossa and Av. Guarino. The favours and ornaments for the cotillion, which were profuse, were ordered from Paris, and the buffet was as artistic in display as it was exquisite in culinary aesthetics. The Bracale orchestra played a choice repertoire that added not a little to the gaiety of the dance, which was kept up with entrain till dawn. Amongst others who deserve a word of praise in connexions with the organization of this ball, we must not forget to mention Messr. Herring and Wenger, the managers of the Casino.

Those present included:- Madams Piui, Giro, Iunes, Pilavachi, Apostolopoulo, Papageorgs, Comtessa Sormasi, Lusens, Nourissos, Comteuse Sakakini Pasha, Drosso bey, Khoury, Adea, Youssouffian Bey, Nasser, Klat, Schemeil, Domani, Chams, Maddemoiselles de Sartores, Loupis, Arbib, Demitri, Yoanaides, Khoury, Khlat, Zohar.

div.head: Mme HADING TO VISIT CAIRO
div.p: Mme Jane Hadin, the celebrated French actress, is to pay a visit to Cairo during the coming season and will give a series of representations. at the Abbas Theatre. Mme Hading is the daughter of an actor, and appeared on the stage at a very early age. Her first appearances were in the provinces, but at the age of seventeen she captivated the somewhat critical audiences of the Paris Palais Royal, and gained equal successes at the Renaissance and Gymnase. She created the famous role of "Sapha," in Daudet's play of that name, which has perhaps been made known to most of our theatre-going readers by Mme. Olga Nethersole. Another role of note which was created by Mme. Hading is that of Claire, in the Maitre de Forges (1883). She was married in 1884 to the famous French actor Victor Koning, against whom she obtained a divorce three years later. She has more than once visited London, where she invariably received a very heart welcome. The presence of so celebrated an actress in Cairo is sure to attract enormous crowds, and most serve as an encouragement to others to make themselves known at the world's greatest winter resort.

div.head: THE SINAI PENINSULA.
div.p: DELIMITATION TREATY ARRIVED.
TURKEY'S CLAIMS WITHDRAWN

The draft of the treaty between the Turkish and Egyptian Governments con erning the delimitation of the Turco-Egyptian frontier by a straight line drawn from Akaba to El Rafeh has been received in Cairo. After being submitted to the Government the treaty will be returned to tje members of the two commissions, who are remaining at Rafeh, and after signed copies of the treaty have been exchanged it will be ratified by the respecting Governments. Although the details of the treaty have not been allowed to transpire we understand that the delimitation has been carried out in a manner entirely to the satisifaction of the Egyptian Government, the objections to the straight line as surveyed between Akaba and El Rafeh and the Turkish claims to an extension of the frontier west of the straight line having been finally withdrawn.
The telegraphic and telephonic line from Suez to Nakhl, which was completed on Wednesday, will only be used at the present for telephonic messages.

div.head: PIGEON SHOOTING CASES.
div.p: A number of cases arising from the pigeon shooting arena, recently installed at Shoubra, came before the Cairo Mixed Contraventions Court at its last sitting. The police want to put a stop to the sport, and have accused the organisers of committing a misdemeanour for violating the law forbidding the use of firearms at a distance lees than 350 metres from inhabited dwellings. The defendants declared that this law did in no way apply to them as its object clearly was to stop the danger to passerby from promiscious firing and that the systematic shooting of pigeons in a carefully enclosed space would not be considered as endangering the safety of the public in the slightest. The defendants also invoked a judgment of the Alexandria Mixed Contraventions Court, which decided in a similar case, in favour of the proprietors of a pigeon shooting arson Judgment will be given on Monday.

div.head: FOUR MEN SUFFOCATED
div.p: Four natives were suffocated on Wednesday morning in a dry well at Cairo, in the Darb Sanenate quarter. The master of the small farm on which this well is situated, El Hag Hussein Ragh by name, told the first of the victims. Sourour-el-Abd, to go down into the well for purpose which is not known.

A quarter of an hour passed, but he did not return, and Hussein Ragh, becoming anxious, ordered another of his men, Said, to go below, he likewise did not return. The master, who was now utterly perplexed at to what should detain his men, went down himself and he was followed by a Copt eneighbour, a jeweller, who had seen the others disappaer thus mysteriously. The farmer's son, who by now suspected that something unusual had happened, informed the Bab el Shariah Caracol. It was however, too late; the four men were already dead before help could come, and after a postmortem they were buried at two o'clock in the afternoon.

Two versions are given to account for this subterranean tragedy;— One is that Hussein Ragh, had ordered Serour to go down to search for a hook used for drawing water, and that he bad been, together with the others, asphyxiated by carbonic acid gas. Another that he had, to save the cost of transport, thrown into the wall the carcase of a young buffalo that had died in the stall, and that the neighbors fearing noxious exhalations therefore had threatened Hussein, with legal proceedings if he did not have the carcases removed. It was the gas produced by the decomposition of the carcass, which, according to this version, has been the cause of death. The results of the police inquiry are not yet known.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Syrian Prince left Manchester Thursday with passengers and general sorgo, and is due taoarrive at Alexandria on or about the 13th of October.
The Elderman S.S. City of Cambridge sailed from Malta last night, and is due here on Tuesday morning with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: NILE AND MARITZA.
div.p: In a pamphlet on trade possibilities between Bulgaria and Egypt M.P. Dimitroff, of the Bulgarian Foreign Office, who lately studied various questions of Egypt and the Soudan, is of opinion that Bulgaria could export to Egypt at a profit such articles as tobacco, flour, beans, cheese, livestock, charcoal, Wood, attar of roves, as well as draperies and cotton goods, in exchange for Egyptian products.
Such an exchange is already supported by the most-favored nation treaty closed this year between the two countries and would be developed by direct steamship lines.

div.head: OBITUARY.
MAJOR L'ESTRANGE JOHNSTONE
div.p: Major J. H. L'Estrange Johnstone, General Manager of the Egyptian Railways, is deed. (Reuter)

Major James H. L'Estrange Johnstone, M.V.O. was born at Alva, Scotland, on the 8th of August 1865 end was the eon of the late James Johnstone and grandson of Lieut.-Col. H. P. l'Estrange of Moyston, Ireland. He received his early education at Eton, from where he passed into the Woolwich Military Academy, and he afterwards studied at the School of Military Engineering, Chatham. He entered the Royal Engineers in 1884 and from 1886 to 1887 he was a military pupil at Sir Wm. Armstrong, Mitchell and Co.'s works at Elawick. In 1888 he was appointed assistant engineer of the 1st grade by the Military Works Department of India and sent to Aden. From 1880 to 1891 he was inspecting officer of the Royal Engineers' Machinery at Malta and the following year he was temporarily employed on the preservation of Abu-Simbel temple by the Ministry of Public Works. From 1894 to 1899 he was inspector of iron structures and railways at the War Office headquarters and he left that post to become President of the Egyptien State Railways. He was made a member of the Royal Victorian Order (4th class) in 1902, and in the following year Grand Officer of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Osmanieh. Major Johnstone married Amy Octavia, daughter of Andrew Wauchope in 1901.

No details of the circumstances which led to the Major's death had been received at the headquarters of the Egyptian Government Railways at Cairo, up to the time of our going to Press. His death was entirely unexpected and he was expected to return to Cairo from Europe at the beginning of next week. Major Johnstone was a man of considerable Intellectual ability and passed first out of Woolwich. Although he cannot be said to have been a railway administrator of the first rank, he was an energetic and conscientious worker and did his best in trying to introduce some efficiency into the Egyptian Government Railways. That he succeeded to a large degree is evidenced by the improved condition of the administration today.
(By Telephone). Cairo, 1.30 p.m.

When the news first reached Cairo this morning it was at first surmised that the announcement referred to one of the Major's eons, as up to only a few day ago letters received from him contained no intimation that he was in anything but the best of health. But the news has been confirmed by a telegram, which passed through Cairo this morning to Sir John Herrington, the British Minister at Adis Abebs, begging him to break the news of the Major's death to his brother, who is at present at Shoa in Abyssinia.
It is presumed that death was due to some accident. At far as is at present known, the Major expired in Switzerland.

div.head: RAMLEH WATER SUPPLY.
A VITAL QUESTION
div.p: A question of the utmost importance for the well being of Alexandria's delightful Eastern suburbs, known under the collective name of Ramleh, is that of the supply of filtered water to the houses. The main water pipes have now been laid down, and the Alexandria Municipality contributed three quarters of the cost of this installation. The balance was paid by the Alexandria Water Company. The mains are ready and everything is, in fact, complete for in Ramleh. But as is usually the case in Egypt, after a great effort is made, the responsible authorities think themselves entitled to a little repose and the result is that no water comes. We here been asked by some of our readers, who live is Ramleh, the reason of this inscrutable delay. As is generally the case in Alexandria, the fault is popularly supposed to lie with the Municipality, which is the scapegoat of the ignorant,but although we are by no means prone to always acquit it of indifference to the public weal, we must allow that is this instance it is entirely absolved. The sole obligation of the Municipality in this case was to supply three-quaters of the money for the main pipes. But the duty of making the filtered water supply of Ramleh of practicable utility rested with the Water Company. How is it that the Company has up to now refrained from fulfiliing this essential obligation? It is to be hoped that the Board of Directors will soon take steps to satisfy the Ramleh public, for the work of connecting the main conducts with the houses rests solely with them.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ismail Pasha Sirry, of the Ministry of Public Works, will return from his holiday in Spain on the 16th of October.
Abdallah Bay Sfer returned to Cairo to-day.
Mr. Anthony, the controller of the Government Land Department, is going on leave early in November.
Mr. J. T. Foxcroft,-Inspector to the Public Lands Department, returns from leave on October 20.
An extended leave of absence has been granted to Captain S.G. Roe, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskillings Fusiliers, until October 31.
Sheikh Ahmet Ibrahim, Ulema of Cairo, has been appointed a professor of law at the Khedivial Law School.
Dr. Nicholas Tsochas, the Athenian physician, who is well known at Alexandria, where he lived for some years, has discovered a new remedy for appendecitis.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: "Al Lewa" and the Syrians
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir, - With reference to the "Lewa's charges of "cowardice and low birth" against the Syrians in consequence of the recent mutiny at Port Said as referred to in your columns on the 27th instant, this is certainly amusing as coming from such a source, when we well remember that Ali Effendi Fahey (now Ali Bay) the brother of his Excellency Mustafa Pasha Kamel and probably the writer of the article is the "gentleman" who as an officer of the Egyptian Army was tried by a General Court Martial by order of Lord Kitchener, at Abbassia in the spring on 1896 and convicted on a charge of cowardice. "Dismissed from his Highness' service as "an officer, and held to serve as a conscript" "private soldier."
After the promulgation of the proceedings of the Court Martial, he was posted to the 7th Egyptian Battalion, with which he served in laying the Sarras-Kums railway during the Dongala expedition.

The "particulars" of the charge on which he was convicted were that when orders were issued for the Egyptian Army to proceed on active service, he, through cowardice, tendered the resignation of his commission in order to avoid proceeding on active service. The Syrians did not rejoice over his downfall.-
Faithfully Yours
One who was Present.
Cairo, September 28.

div.head: POSTAL ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir.-The correspondence upon the above subject in your valuable paper led me to refer to your summary of H.E. Saba Pasha's Report for 1905m in which I find that 4,300,000 letters were dispatched in that year to Great Britain, Malta, and Gibraltar alone. Taking the most moderate estimate of half an ounce weight per letter, there was, then, a discrimination of 4,479 3s. 4d. as against this country. This figure would no doubt be enormously swelled if the dispatch of letters to other places which have a convention for reduction of letter postage with Egypt were included, even when leaving out of account the probability that thousands of the letters weighed more than half an ounce. But that is not all. The figures I have taken—the latest available—relate to a period before the reduction of rates was put in force. That the number of letters sent from this country has increased by one half at least in consequence of such reduction is a legitimate inference from the increase which have taken place by reason of such reduction in other parts of the world.

It would seem pairing strange in any other country which has to any extent adopted Western methods that the Post Office Report for 1905 should have taken nearly ten months in preparation. Chi va piano va sand is a very good old adage, but is quite inapplicable in the instance under consideration. At the present rate of progress, we shall have to wait another year before we are able to calculate approximately the excess rate which is still being charged. I hope with another correspondent of yours that someone in our British Parliament will make the welkin ring with this fresh grievance of the Egyptian public, for thus and thus alone are we likely to obtain equality of treatment—I am, etc.,
Mercurius
Alexandria, 27th September.

div.head: THE CAIRO POLICE.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—I notice a letter in yesterday's issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" signed "Bobby" on the want of a Caracol at Kasr el Nil. Surely a Caracol is far more wanted in the Kasr el Doubara quarter! In case of any trouble, it is here that the British Agent and the G.O.C. of the Army of Occupation live and yet in view of the Pan Islamic unrest they have no protection. Truly yours
Forewarned, Forearmed. Kasr el Doubara, Cairo, 27th September.

div.head:
ADDRESS TO LORD MILNER
BRITISH ANTI-NATIONALISM.

div.p: Lord Milner, receiving an address from 25,000 Cape Colonists praising his services, said that the danger in South Africa was disunion but that a far greater danger was the growth of the spirit of anti nationalism in Great Britain, owing to which South Africa was the special sufferer. Anti-nationalism was a great growing factor threatenirn every part of the Empire, but once Great Britain awoke to the strength which it has acquired she would unite in a tremendous rally to preserve the Empire. (Reuter)

div.head:
STORMS IN THE STATES
COTTON SUFFERS SEVERELY
LOSSES IN PENSACOLA 2,000,000 DOLLARS.

div.p: Owing to storms and rain wide areas in Louisiana and other southern states have been flooded. The news is disquieting ii cotton circles but it is believed that the damage done is not serious. (Reuter)

The latest storms have caused extensive damage. Cotton in Alabama has suffered severely. The waterfront of Pensacola is strewn with the wreckage of ships and wharves. The losses in Pensacola and vicinity alone exceed two million dollars. (Reuter)

div.head:
AMERICAN MONEY MARKET
TREASURY MAKES HEAVY DEPOSITS

div.p: It is announced that the Treasury has made a deposit of twenty six million dollars into the banks of various cities which will become returnable when the pressure in the money market in over. It is expected to relieve the drain of gold caused by the London market. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE CRETAN INSURGENTS
NUMEROUS ARRESTS EXPECTED

div.p: Numerous rioters who signalized the occasion of the departure of Prince George by endeavouring to raise disturbances have been arrested. Their ringleaders have fled or are in hiding. 240 French troops from Marseeilles and 292 Italian troops from Messina have been sent to the disturbed districts. (Reuter)

The prison administrative in a confidential circular to the governors states that a new strong terrorist organization has been formed with the object of releasing political prisoners by besieging the prisons. (Reuter)
The terrorists have killed the director of the military hospital and prison. (Havas)
General Stoessel has been compulsorily retired. Further proceedings in connection with the surrender of Port Arthur have been quashed. (Reuter)
A duel has been fought between M. Woivodich and M. Cantoni. M. Woivodich was wounded in the arm (Havas)
The Socialist Congress has confirmed the decision of the Congress of Iena, recognising in principle the general politic strike of the masses. (Havas)
A cyclone has devastated the town of Nemours. Several deaths have taken place and the damages are great. (Havas)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Sir William H. May is mentioned as a likely successor of Lord Charles Beresford in command of the Mediterranean Fleet, when the latter vacates it to take up the command of the Channel Fleet.

Brigadier General Dawson, C.V.O., commanding the 17th Infantry Brigade, inspected the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers at Belfast yesterday. The battalion, numbering 600 of all ranks under Colonel Mackenzie, looked particularly fine.

Amongst the officers appointed to the battleship Formidable on re-commissioning for further service with the Mediterranean Fleet, are the following - commandar P. W. E. Hill, Lieutenants C. W. Bruton (first and gunnery officer), H. 0. Reinold (navigating officer) K. Kiddle (torpedo officer): Acting Lieutenant W H. Dickson, Royal Naval Reserve (for 12 months training); Engineer Commander E.F. Sparks (re-appointed), Engineer Lieutenants H. H. Johnson, and R. A. Howley; Captain and Brevet Major E. Wray. Royal Marine Light Infantry, Lieutenant F.G. Cook, Royal Marine Artillery: Fleet Surgeon W. Bowden, D.S.O. Staff Paymaster E.A. Redman, Surgeon A.K. Shand-Smith, Engineer Sub Lieutenant G. Robbins, Artificer Engineers P. S. Johns and J. W Day.

In a few weeks Brevet Colonel C.W. Napier Clavering, The Prince Albert's (Somersstshire Light Infrantry), will vacate the command of the 1st Battalion at Cawnpore under the four years regulation. Colonel Napier-Clavering will sever his connection with the regiment after an association of over 28 years as he got his first commission in the old 13th Light Infantry in May, 1878. He commanded a company from 1886 to 1896, when he was promoted major and attained to the command of the 1st Battalion on the 13th November, 1902. He saw service in the Burmese Expedition, 1885 87 (medal with clasp). The command should go to Major C. H. Stisted, second in command of the battalion.

The S.S.Dongola leaves Southampton to-morrow (21st inst ) en voyage for Bombay, with the 2nd Battalion Leicestershire Regiment, Brevet Colonel E.R. Scott commanding, and a number of Royal Artillery drafts and other details on board for various parts of "The Shiny." The Leicesters go to Belganm, where the 1st Battalion is stationed. The latter will return home by the Bengala. The; liner is due at Port Said on the 1st October, and at Bombay about the 11th and will leave that port on the 19th following on the home ward voyage, Southampton being reached about the 9th November. The 1st Leicesters will be stationed at Shorncliffs on arrival home.

The tendency in the home army just now is to Withdraw more gunmen from the forte to form more heavy Field Batteries. The 10 pounder gun, with which the heavy batteries are armed isae very fine weapon, of great range and penetration, and its usefulness was fully demonstrated in the most recent maneuvers. Of course it is a bit ponderous, but when well horsed can move with wonderful celerity. Within the past few weeks boards of officers have visited various places in England and Scotland for the purposes of "spotting out" ranges for Mr. Haldane's projected Royal Field Artillery Militia regiments.

A special Army Order just promulgated ordains that no officer shall be considered eligible for the command of a regiment of cavalry, or a battalion of infantry, unless he has returned to regimental duty at least twelve months immediately before the vacancy occurs, except in cases where the vacancy is caused by unforeseen circumstances. A captain, after at least six years service, and a major or lieutenant colonel may be promoted to the next highest rank by brevet for distinguished service in the field. It is further ruled that an officer may draw full pay whilst on sick leave for the following periods - (1), ordinary cases for a period not exceeding 12 months. (2)- In very special cases, such as the loss of health due to tropical service, or active operations, the period may be extended, but it shall not exceed 12 months in all.

The War office has rated that a captain or major employed under the Egyptian Government shall be removed from his regiment and placed on half pay if he is continued in such employment for more than ten years, or beyond the date on which he would ordinarily have to return to regimental employment in order to qualify for commend. Some half dozen officers will have to make their elections shortly.

The King has been graciously pleased to give orders for the following appointments toDistinguished Service Order and promotion in Army in recognition of services of the under mentioned officers during operations in Northern and Southern Nigeria: —

To be Companions of the Distinguished Service Order Captain and Brevet Major Hugh Montagne Trenehard, the Royal Scots Fusiliers; Captain G. The King has also been graciously pleased to approve of the following promotions in recognition of the services of the undermentioned officers during the operations of the Nardi Expeditionary Forces in the East Africa Protectorate, October, 1905 — February, 1906:-

To be Majors—Captain H.Walker, Royal Fusiliers(City of London Regiment), Captain L. Pope Hennessy, Oxford hire Light Infantry.

The King has further been graciously pleased to approve of the grant of the Medal for Distinguished Conduct in the Field to Sergeant F.W. Angus, Seaforth Highlanders (Ross shire Buffs, the Duke of Albany's) in recognition of his gallant conduct during the operations in the Bends Ouitsha Hinterland, Southern Nigeria, and of the grant of the medal for Meritorious Service to Staff Sergeant L Woodell, Royal Army Medical Corps, who has been mentioned in despatches for valuable and meritorious service during the operations in the Munshi country, Northern Nigeria.

div.head: CARRIED HOME IN AGONY CURED BY DOAN'S BACKACHE KIDNEY PILLS.
div.p: Mr Arthur Joyce, 11, St. George Road, Regent's Park, Leaden. England, writes - "Dear Sirs— Before I began with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills I was positively unable to stoop or lift anything, without having dreadful pains in the back. At times I have also had stoppage of urine and have been in such agony that I have had to be carried home from work, and the doctor has had to be sent for.

The secretions from the kidneys were jelly-like, and at times there would be a red, sandy sediment from them. At nights I would have to leave the bed many times. I have been under hospital treatment, as well as under the doctor at home, but got little relief until I began with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills. I wrote you some time ago, saying how the medicine had helped me, and I write again to say that I am still improving. There is now regular passage of secretions, and the only thing I notice now is a slight discolouring of the urine, which, I feel sure, will be put right before I have been using your medicine much longer. Yours truly, (Signed) Arthur Joyce."
Over two years later- Mr. Joyce said:" I am very thankful to say that I am still enjoying good health."
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13P.T. per box.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
div.p: Church and State In France.

Plus X., we are assured, is convinced that the French Government is bent on gradually dechristianising France, and that the Separation is a conscious movement in this direction. M des Hoax and his liberal Catholic friends, on the other hand, see "Germano Roman manoeuvres" everywhere in the recent development of Papal policy. There may be, and no doubt there is, an element of foundat on for these suspicions on either aide - though, so far as the French Government is concerned, M. Briand, the author of the Separation Law, has categorically denied any such designs as those attributed to it by the Pope. But it is impossible not to feel that too elaborate apprehensive of this kind only breed fresh distrust and misunderstanding, and in the Pope's ease may launch the Church on a course far more disastrous to its interests than a simple acceptance of the Separation Law would appear to us to be. ("Times.")

"Rulers of the Waves." Since - Britain first at Heaven's command Arose from out the azure main," she has never on one day committed to the charge of the sea three such huge vessels as those which were launched yesterday at Wallsend-on-Tyne, Belfast, and Chatham respectively. Two of these monsters of the deep are to be devoted to the peaceful and pacifying business of trade and passenger traffic, though the Mauretania will also be a sort of citizen soldier of the seas, being armed and adapted as a scout or cruiser, while the speed of the Shannon will enable her to act as the natural protector, in time of war, of the vast merchant shipping for which swiftness is less important than economical transport of cargo.

The simultaneous launch of there mighty ships, though the simultaneity was quite undesigned, proves that we can turn out from these shores at the shortest possible notice more formidable vessels than any of our maritime rivals. Nothing can wrest from Great Britain the "command of the sea" save the supineness of our rulers and the indifference of our people. There is a great deal of nonsense talked about "militarism," but happily no one has yet discovered that "navalism" is a possible form of national disease. Even the "Little England" has come to recognise that "Little England" would not be safe were there no powerful Fleet to defend its not inacessible shores ("Telegraph.")

div.head: Britain and Turkish Import Outlet.
div.p: We are glad to see, from the Constantinople telegrams, that Sir Edward Grey is not yet prepared to sanction the increase of the Turkish import duties from 8 to 11 per cent. English diplomacy has rarely had in its hands a more useful weapon than this,and it would be deplorable if our assert were given without obtaining some very considerable concessions in return. Our trade still accounts for 69 per cent of the whole imports affected, and we have therefore every right to sell our assent dear. It is quite proper, we think, since our trade must suffer somewhat by the increase, that the opportunity should be seised of settling such outstanding commercial grievances as those of the British Smyrna-Aidin Railway Company.

To a great extent, also, we share the fears of Mr Lynch and other Bagdad merchants, who think that if this fresh revenue is granted to Turkey, even under the stipulation that its proceeds are to go to the relief of the Macedonian Budget, it will provide a basis on which capital could be raised to finance the German Bagdad Railway. We are by no means hostile in principle to that railway, but we should not like to see it financed this obscure and furtive way , before the capital is provided for it, England ought to be in a position to safeguard the interests which she has at stake in Mesopotamia and the Persaen Gulf. ("Tribune.")

div.head: Our Navy's Pressing Needs.
div.p: Our unchallenged predominance at sea has owed much to the fact that our wealth allowedns to expend more money on gun practice and more money on coal, than any other Power, and permitted of our ships, individually and collectively, being kept in full repair and ready for any emergency. And it is largely because we were able to keep at sea so many more days in the year than the Fleet of other nation that the British Navy has become what it is. All that is a thing of the past, and harassed admirals and captains are compelled to witness under their eyes the rapid deterioration of their ships for want of proper maintenance and repair. There can be only two results of the present system. En he we shall awake one fine morning, in a panic, as we have often done before, and lavish millions to get back the efficiency and supremacy we have thrown away, or else the awakening will come too late, when our rivals have gone beyond us, and have judged that the movement for striking is ripe. And from that catastrophe there will be no recovery. ("Globe.")

div.head: Turkey and tha Balkans.
div.p: If ever the inhabitants of the vilayets which the Porte has abandoned to anarchy are to find relief they will obtain it at the hand of some neutral and disinterested Power, which has nothing to gain or lose from any territorial readjustment that may be considered necessary in the interests of European peace. All the Governments which feel most lively concern in the affairs of the Balkans are disqualified by the fact that none will trust any of the others, and hitherto no outside Power has consented to undertake a thankless and invidious task. Meantime, the condition of Macedonia goes from bad to worse. Nobody attaches import ancs to the sanguine accounts which are from time to time presented by eminent statesmen for the benefit of philanthropic inquirers. The one object of Constantinople statesmanship is procrastination, since the Sultan and his clique of perversley subtle advisers are convinced that reform is but another name for emancipation from Ottoman rule. Nothing would be more satisfactory to Europe than for the Ports itself to set up a decent system of government, and thus exempt other Powers from the duty of a supervision equally wearisome and ineffective. ("Standard.")

div.head: A Black Year For the Jews.
div.p: Full of suffering and terror as Jewish years have often been, we suppose that seldom in recent generations have they suffered so terribly as in the twelve months past. The names of Odessa, Warsaw, Bielostok, and Siellce will not be forgotten in their history. Nor will the revelations of Prince Urusoff the Russian Dima be forgotten-revelations describing how when he was in the Ministry of Interior be discovered an official printing press from which circulars inciting to the massacre of Jews were issued by thousands, while the official in charge boasted he could supply a massacre of ten or ten thousand as desired just as though he were a fashionable caterer contracting for luncheons. The mere introduction of the Russian word "pogrom" or Jewish massacre into all the languages of Europe within the last few months proves how atrocious has been the persecution of the year. nor is it possible to excuse the Russian Government from complicity in the crimes. ("Chronicle")

div.head: A Grave Responsibility
div.p: "M. Stolypin declined to go into details, but solemnly assured Barca Gersberg and M. Slicsberg that no further Jewish massacres would occur." ("Times" St Petersburg telegram.) "The Governor General and the Prefect of Odessa have informed the Chief Rabbi that they will not allow any disorder and will mercilessly quell any pogrom at the very beginning." We are, indeed, glad to be assured that there are to be no more pogams, but M. Stolypin's promise is surely a grave admission. If the Jews can now be safeguarded, why up to now have they been at the mercy of their assailants? If the Russian Government can now give an absolute guarantee against massacres- how is it could not or did not do so before? Still, it will be a great improvement of a new chapter is really begun, whatever may be the facts as to the last chapter ("Westminster Gazette.")

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE
div.p: The Ports and Lighthouses Administration has decided to construct a shelter house, and other buildings for pilgrims at Port Tewfik.

It is gratifying to be able to announce that the appeal published in "The Daily Telegraph" of the 13th inst., on behalf of the Mohamadan community of India, for the removal of the harassing and unnecessary quarantine imposed at Bombay upon pilgrims going to Mecca, has had a very prompt result. Last week Mr. F.F. Gordon, of the "Advocate of India, who has interested himself in this question, received a telegram from Mr. Adamjee Peerbhoy, one of the leaders of the Mohamedans in India, stating that the vexatious quarantine had been abolished, and expressing sinners thanks for the aid given to Moslems in securing this result.

As Mr. Gordon explained in his article, the grievance complained of seemed a small one, but in reality was a very important matter to pious followers of the Prophet desiring to perform the pilgrimage to Mecca. Instead of mere medical inspection at Bombay they were subjected to a 5 days' quarentme in a camp;-, admission to which was often only procured after long delay, and this was in addition to the quarentine imposed by the Turkish Government at Kamran near Jeddah. Hence they had to undergo great hardships and serious expense before even starting on their journey. Happily this has now been remedied, and no doubt the decision will greatly please the Indian Mohamedans, who are among the most devoted and loyal supporters of British rule in Hindustan.

div.head: SULTAN OBJECTS TO CHIOROFORM
div.p: Dr. Burgmann, the eminent surgeon summoned from Berlin by the Sultan, has been enable to perform the necessary operations, owing to the Sultan's refusal to be placed under chloroform. The Sultan wished Dr Burgmann to perform the operation, and declared he was quite capable of supporting it without as anesthetic. The doctor refused to operate under these circumstances.

div.head: Notice. SUDAN GOVERNMENT
div.p: Disposal of Building Sites at Port Sudan The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Leases will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent.

Example: If a plot leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lease will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc.) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Officers are invited of Premium for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours.

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN.
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan AVIS Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains a hait a Port-Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emptyéotique, pour une durée de 80 années a partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, a charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'a partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables a perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé a la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augments ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années a partir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, a l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (a condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi a perpétuité.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéctiques dont s'agit; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionnaire est disposé a payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement a la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues a Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offres, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront a la disposition du Public a partir du 1er Octobre 1906, aux Beux ci-aprés indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*-Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Sudan (T).
Port-Soudan*- Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim- Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.

Londres- Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez- Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Représentant du Ministére de la Guerre.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Cotons

Exportations modérées et laissant craindre, comme premiére impression, une semaine peut être passatisfaisante de ce chef, recettes se développant tout d'un coup et effectivement fortes en comparaison de celles de la semaine correspondante en 1905, cloture d'Amérique peu brillante et, finalement, marché pour le disponible sans entrais et en baisse, voila les diverges raisons qui ont permis aux baissiers de faire fléchir le Novembre a 16 17/32 sois 3/16 au dessins de la veille.

Ce concours de circonstances que nous venons d'énumérer n'était certainement guére encourageant, mais d'autre part, dans tout cels il u'y avait, au fond, rien d'assez grave pour justifier le mouvement de faiblesses au point atteint. L.exagérat on était douc patents et tout le monde le reconnaissait, seulement cela cula pas empêché l'ouverture de lundi d'être mauvaise, car, sauf étions, quantion réste, logés, a peu prés a la meme enseigne. Des le déut, séanmoins, on remarquait que les vendeurs sérieux n'existaient pas, et la chose devint évidente quand, un pen plus tard, une certaine, demande est surgie: a partir de ce moment, le changement d'allure a été complet et pour le restant de la réance c'est la fermeté qui a prévalu, en nous faisant monter de 16 7/16 a 16 9/16, pour cloturér a 16 17/32 schemers.

Toutefois, cette amélioration ne s'est pas maintenance le lendemain, et quoique dans l'ensemble le ton soit resté acutenu, c'est su perte de 1/16 que le novembre a été affiché. Les fluctuations ont été limitées a été 16 7/16 et 16 17/32 et dans les raisons qui influençaient le marché depuis le premier jours, il nil avait réellement du mieux que dans la question du disponible qui a été actif et en bonne demande.
Le cas a été absolument la meme pour la journée de mercredi qui a fini avec 1/8 de baisse altérieure et tondeurs a cause des arrivages jugés trop importants en comparison de l'année derniére.
Comme tenue, la réance de jeudi a ressemblé a celle de la vielle, mais sous le rapport des prix, le recul s'est limité a 1/32.

Finalement, la matinée d'aujourd'hui nous affect une lueur d'espéance, la tenue du marché fendant toute la matinée ayant été toute différente de ce a quoi nous avions fini par nous habituer depuis quelques jours le courant d'affaires a été avare satisfaisant et la evite finale a été de 16 1/2 pour le novembre, soit en reprise de 5/32 sur le minimum pratiqué pendant la semaine, mais nous lissant quand meme une perte de 11/32 sur la cote de Vendredi dernier.

La tendance pour le moment semble meilleure, mais on ne saurait officier que cela dourer longtemps avec une spéculation qui a l'air de vouloir agir un peu trop superficiellement, pourquoi toute cette pour en face du développement des arrivages? Le fait a'était pas inattendu, car aprés tout ce haut prix attire toujours la marchandise, sans compter que les gros cultivateurs ayant déja vendu pour les plupart, leur intéret aujourd'hui consiste a livrer leur récolte au far et a mesure que le coton est cueilli, et cela pour en touchar in valeur un moment plus tot. Certes, les grosses quantités impressionnent tonours un marché spéculatif, mais cela ne devrait pas extra a un point aussi marqué? Et puis, a ce mauvais coté de la situation du moment, pourquoi ne pas opposer la question sériesse des engagements de l'exportation envers la filature? Depuis, sail y a eu beaucoup de marchandise offerte a la vente, est il resté quelque chose qui etait pas trouvé amateur, soit coutre suciennes affaires, soit contre nouveaux ordres venue de l'Angleterre, car il est incontestable que es dernier pays, qui ne s'est pas approvisioneté est le grand acheteur du jour pour prompt embarquement. Da reste, la chose était préves depuis longtemps avec l'épuisement des ressources invisibles en cotons égyptiens et il faut meme s'attendre a use accentuation de la demande de ce cotella.

Pour ce qui est des futurs, il y avait en cessation de demande de la part de la consommation, mais la rentrée soudains de nos exportateurs comme acheteurs de contrats aprés qu'ils avaient commencé a montrer des vel'étes de vendre, prouverait que la baisse a de nouveau attiré la filature anglaise.

Il est d'ailleurs constaté depuis quelque a ops que cheque fois que nous arrivons au niveau de 16 1/4, les ordres d'achat ne manquent pas du dehors, ce qui nous force a croire qu'a moise de quelque événement extraordinaire, ce serait la la véritable moyenne de la valeur de nos cotons.

Tout ce que nous pensons la, a'exclut certes pas la possibilité d'une baisse, mai ce qu'on ne saurait admettre c'est qu'elle puis sidaus les circonstances actuelles, se produire a bref délai. Il y aura trop de desaude pour le disponible pour des semaines encore, sans compter que du coté de la récolte on s'est pas tout a fait tranquille. Dams l'état plus a craindre mais en coupe comme sortons d'une campagne pont ainsi dure épuiés et avec due grande l'escious pour celle qui vient de commercer, at naturellement ecoindre dégat sera toujours sensiblement ressenti. En dehors de la question des brouillards et de leurs dégata possibles a la deuxième cueille ta le Nili on troisiéme cueillette n'est pas encore en poche et il lei fondrait encore une viegtaire de jours de bonnes chaleurs pour donner anebonneréussite.

Ce sont des choses qu'il se faut pas perdre de vue, comme aussi il ne faut pas tout a fait câbler la question de l'Américan et de l'appui qu'il pourrait sours office. On a beau dire et beau raisonner, le cours de 5 perce ext bon marché pour l'état actual de l'industrie cotonniére, surtout si les nouvelles de délas a la récide venaient a étre confirmées, ne fut-ce que partiellement. Il est indéniable que le découvert spéculatif est énorme en Amérique et la écéche Reuter disant que la Bourse est inquété fait que reflétar l'impression produite par les avis d'excés de plus et d'mandations en Louisiana et sill ears.

Relevons encore en passant que la spéculation commence a se porter sur les echéeance éhigrées. On a déja inauguré le Mainates 1/4 de taller sur le Mars et ce dernier s'est déja mis su meme niveau que le Novembre. Le déport sur Janvier tend aussi a diminuer.

La marché du disponible, aprés un moment de faiblement, s'est raffermi et dans l'ensemble il a été setif. Les Provenances Haute-Egypte sont toujours en favour et ce qui étoune un pen c'est que l'Angleterre en prend avec plaisir. Les Mit Afifi ont été un pen négligés a cause du prix vraisemblablement, mais comme la valeur de ce genre de coton tend a se régulariser avec l'augmentation des arrivages, la demande ne tarder pas a s'y porter, d'autant plus qu'il faudra bientôt penser a l'exécution des engagements existants sur Octobre.
En attendant le résumé de la cote officielle nous montre une baisse de 1/8 sur les flaute- Egypte et de 7/8 sur les Mit Affifi.

La Premiére enchére des Domaines a eu lieu hier et elle a donné des résultats considérées comme satisfaisants pour la dite Administration. On rapporte, mais nous ne garantissons rien, que les Domaines ne semblent pas tout a fait aurs d'une bonne récolte.

Les exportations de la remaine out fini par atteindre les prévisions avec leur total de 7,900 Balles, contre 6,600 Balles en 1905 pour la meme période. Les persecpetives pour la remaine prochaine sont encore meilleures, meme comparativement a l'année derniére avec son chiffre de 13,400 Balles.

Ajoutons a ce propos et en passant que les exportations de l'année derniére pour Octobre on été de 60,000 Balles environ et que celles de Novembre se sont élevées a 190,000 Balles. On s'attend a plus pour le mois prochain, male il est difficile que Novembre 1905 soit dépassé, quote la possibilité ne doive pas être exclue. Liverpool a été peu actif pour les égyptiens disponibles et les vente u'out résllement augmeuté qu'avec la baisse du spot a 9 1/2. La Septembre coté a 9 12/64 a aussi perdu 10/64 durant la semaine, mais le Novembre reste inchar géta 8 30/64,

Les améicains aussi ont été calmes, faute de marchandise de bonne qualité pour alimenter les affaires, mais pout ce qui est des prix il y a un peu de hausse, soit 9 points sur le spot a 5.66 et 2 et1 points sur les futurs cotés ce soir a 5.07.

div.head: Graines de Coton.
div.p: La bonne demande pour le disponible a maintenu la valeur de l'article a P.T. 68 et cela malgré l'augmentation des arrivages.
Les exportations de la semaine ost été relativement bonnes, mais pour octobre on est en droit de s'attendre a un chiffre satisfaisant, a en juger du moins par les affrérements connus

En contrats, le mouvement d'affaires a été presque insignificant pour la semaine qui vient de finir, car la spéculation persiste plus que jamais dans sou abstention, tandis que les chats de l'exportation, qui s'est pas toujours forcée de recourir aux contrats pour couvrir see opérations a l'étranger, ne sont ni réguliers ni sufficiente pour alimentes le marché.
Hull schéts, mais tout doucement et dans tous les cas en évitant de faire la hausse. Meme pour le septembre, elle a réduit son prix a 6. 16/3.
Pour premiére quinzaine octobre, elle pais 6. 11/3, mais pour les 3 mois elle s'en tient a 6.2/6 et 6.3/9. Alexandrie refuse de vendre a ce dernier cours.

div.head: FEVES:
div.p: On les a affichése pour deux ou trois jours a P.T. 106 l'octobre, mais aujour'hui on les a cotées a 110. Tout cela pourtant est faction ou du mois nominal, la réalité étant que personne ne s'occupe de l'article.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
div.p: SECTION COTONNIERE
Questionnaire de Septembre 1906
Priére de réspondre avant le 5 Octobre en vous servant de la langue que vous préférex
1.—Dites-nous si la température en Septembre a été favorable
2. — Dites nous l'on a constaté des vers et des brouillards en Septembre?
3. —Ces différentes causes ont-elles fait des dégâts aux Cotonniers, et à combien les estimez vous?
4.- La cueillette a-t-elle commencé, et jusqu'à quel point est-elle en avance ou en retard, chez vous en comparaison de l'ancée passée?
5. —Croyez vous que la première cueillette sera supérieure à celle de l'an dernier et de combien?
6.—Que penne vous des perrprotives, de la cueillette de coton dite "Nili"?
7.—La récolte, chez vous, séra-t-elle supérieure ou inférieure à la précédente et de combien?
8. - Le rendement a l'égrenage est il égal, supérieur ou inférieur à celui de l'année dernière et de combien pour cent, pour: le Mit-Afifi? l'Abassi? le Joanovich? l'Ashmouni?
9.- Quel est l'aspect des cultures en général?
Pour le Comité
Le Président en fonction
H. Lindemann.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
Alexandrie, le 28 septembre.
div.p: La situation générale s'est ressentie de la hausse du taux d'escompte en Angleterre à 4 1/2 pour cent et bien que l'ensemble des positions ne soit nullement surchargé et que la liquidation de fin septembre semble devoir s'offecteur sans aucune difficulté à Paris comme a Londres, la spéculation n'en garde pas soins une certaine iréserve. Il est vrai que la tas est retonbré hier da 1/8 b 4 8/8 % Bai. d'antre part la réserve du la banque «a trouve rédei e de 47 1/8 % 4 42 7/8 %. La Consolidé anglain n'en gagna pas moins 1/8 4 86 1/8 Quant eux valeurs égyptiennes, elles restant stationnaire', excepté la National Bank of Egypt qui pard 1/4 da lineà 88 4/1. A Paru la no revenant n'est pas uniforme la Datte Egyptienne Unifiée, l'action de Suez, le Crédit Lyonnais, et la Banque Ottoman sont an baisse, tandis que le Crédit Fonoiar Egygtien. la Comptoir National d'Escompte, la Banque de Athénes at la Crédit Franco-Egyptian sont en hausse.

Ioi, la place a commencé ses emprunta a Londres peur les besoins da la récolte cotonneiére niére at dans la prévision du re*Mrr*mant monétair la conséquence habitualla les banques locales ont augmenté leurs taux d'intérêt ou sont sur la point da la taire. Ce taux varia de 6 à 8 pour cent Un certain nombre de spéculateurs armant déjà Jugé l'ocsion favorable pour opérer 4 la berna; nuit leurs opérations n'ayant pas au tout le succès qu'ile en attendaient, ils ont ara prudent da se convrir avant In fin da mon C'eut ce qui expliqua avec la hausse du taux de l'escompte en Angleterre la baisse du début de la semaine, suivie d'une reprise qui raméne les cours sensiblement au même niveau. A part cala, les affaires n'ont guère eu plus d'importance que la affaires passée. Il s'ensuit quels liquidation de fia du mois parera presque inaparcue, comme me les précédentes. Le mois prochain nous aurons probablement un mouvement plus considérable. car un grand nombre de capitalistes sont déja rentrés d'Europe et ceux qui restent encore rentreront mum doute doute la courant d'octobre.

Aprés quatre jours de chômage, notre Bonne i est trouvés lundi an face d'une forte augmentation du taux privé d'escompte 4 é 1/8 % et des marchés euro; éans troub'és par l'émigration continuelle de l'or aux Estats-Unis, deux circonstances peu laites pour relevar notre place déprimés per l'abstention des capitalistes et les mauvaises nouvelles du dehors. Aussi la la baisse a telle été générale. Dés mardi, cependant, la spéculation s'est mairie et la découvert inquiet commencent a se racheter, détarmiaé une repries peu sensible, mais presque générale. La dessus le taux d'escompte est retombé é 4 1/8 et la arias Meériom a a garda da aaa acuité "Les demandes d'or de Amérique commencent, en effet, a devenir moins pressantes et on n'appréhende plus que la Banque d'Angleterre soit obligée de porter »a taux d'encompte 4 4 les pour cent. D'ailleurs leurs l'eutervention du trévor américain mettait immédiatement a la disposition des banques des sommes égales au montant qu'elles out commandé a l'étranger a produit eu effet sensible sur les conditions, on comprend que l'avenir se préssent sous de meilleurs auspices.

Sur une cinquantaine de valeurs, inscrites a la cote officielle de la bourse da notre ville, 13 sont as hausse, lé au berne at les autres demeurent stationnaires. Les principales fluctuations sont a 4 le Essaie, la Béhéra qui gagne ne demi livre è M l/i, la Dalla Laad S 28 4 3 1/2, et le Comptois 1/8 a 6 19/32 a la baisse, la National Bank qui paré l a à 86 7 16, la dividende Tramways d'Alexandrie 5 francs a 338, la Khedivial Mail 3/32 a 4 9/16, la Land Bank 3/32 a 8 29/32 et la Building Lands 1/16 a 4 7/8. Ce sont la eu somme des fluctuations presque insignifiantes. La part de fondateur Comptoir, qui avait fléchi jusqu'a 41 1/2 a complétement regagné aujourd'hui a 43 l'avance qu'elle avait perdu. Par contre, les Sucreries, qui avaient été poussées jusqu'a 27, sont revenues en cloture a 25 1/2.

Le bruit a couru en housse que le Crédit Franco-Egyptien devait distribuer un fort dividende, 8 shillings. Nous sommes en mesure de diresque cette nouvelle est dénués de tout fondement. Rien ils encore été décidé a ce ajuste par le conseil d'administration de cette société.

Nous avows signalé la baec-e aussi acudaine qu'impréue de la Central Building . Oubliés jus'qua ce jour, elle vient de se réveiller avec cent pour cent de hausse a 10 Livres. On a meme pratiqué le cours de 12 et c'est sur des réalisations de profits qu'on a fléchi a 10 Des renseignements que nous aven pu obtenir sur les motifs de cette hausse, il semble résultar qu'elle provient d'use importante demande de Londres.

En ce qui concerne la Delta Land on parle d'un coupon lutérimair de 10%, c'est a dire de 2 shelling par action, es qui est plutôt une déception pour les détenteurs. Ou ajoute bien que la société va vendra aux enchéres 125,000 m.c. de terrains urbains qu'elle avait acquis a Ben a P.T. 8 le métre et pour lesquels on lei aurait fait des offres a P.E. 75, mais cette derniére nouvelle ne semble pas avoir été prise su sérieux, car le cours n'a gagné en somme qu'un huitiéme. En effet, il est prudent d'attendre le résultat de cette opération.

La Banque d Abyssine est défavorablement influencée par l'allure que prennent les affaires dans ce pays. L'empereur Ménélik, a ce qu'on dit, se montre fort mécontent de ce que les puissances intéressées se partagent son empire par sones d'influence et pour témoigner son mécontentement il aurait meme refusé dernié rement de signer l'accord y relatif, intervenu entre l'Angleterre, la France et l'Italie. Quoi- qu'il en soit, la Banque d'Abyssine qui avait attract un moment 9, est offerte maintenant a 6 1/2, soit a 1 3/2 au-fessous du prix d'émission.
L'Agricole demeure sans affaires on a peu prés a 9 11/16-9 21/32.
C'est surtout la National Cank, Cassa di Sconto, Delta Land, Salt & Soda et Comptoir que des transactions out eu lieu.

La Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte vient de proroger jusqu'au 31 décembre le délai d'option des porteurs pour l'estampille de leurs titres, primitivement fixé au 20 septembre.

A le dernière assemblée du conseil d'aministration du Land and General Trust, tenue a Londres, le président a dit que la société avait refusé une offre qui laissant 30,000 livres de bénéfice sur le vente du Ghorbal Estate, situé a Alexandrie, et 7.000 livrée sur un autre terrain. La situation exceptionnelle de cepropriétés permet, a-t-il dit, de réaliser des profite beaucoup plus importante et il est préférable pour les actionnaires d'attendre une meilleure occasion que de toucher un dividende. D'antre part, on dit que M. Toriel, directeur de le acciété, aurait offert ee démission.

Les titres fonciers sont particulièrement soutenus. Sans parler de la Béhéra qui avance d'une demi livre, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien gagne é francs à 839, la Delta Land 1/S il 1/9, la Nile Land 1/16 è 14 14/16, les Estates 1/32 à 1 27/32 , le Cheikh Fadl, l'Urbaine et l'Union Foncière sont excessive ment fermes aux cours respectifs de 113, 6 1/8 et 6- 11 y e des raisons pour croire que celles de ces valeurs qui ne vont pas trop poussées seront particulièrement favorisèes loti du prochain mouvement de hausse, a cause de la plus value constante et énorme des terrains.

Mess. Rizzo & Co, éditeurs-propriétaires de l'Egyptian Directory (l'Annuaive Egyptien) tiennent à mettre le Public en garde contre les agissements de certaines personnes qui sollicitent et se font remettre d'avencé de l'argent pour insertions et announces dans des publications qualifiées' de différenta titres et qui n'ont jamais vu le jour.

Afiu d'éviter toutes confusions et surprises Mess. Rizzo & Co informant le Publioc d'Alexandrie que toutes insertions et annoncés dans l'Egyptian Directory doivent être remises à leurs Agents, Mess. Fern. Gallois Co, et sont payables après apparition du volume:

Grâce à la collaboration de leurs nombreux Agents, Mess. Rizzo & Co ont apporté d'importantes modifications et rectifications à leur édition 1907, qui paraîtra en Janvier prochain, et ils se flattent de présenter au Public un ouvrage toujours plus complet, plus correct et plut intéressant.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic

MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL ENGINEERS, ALSO SHIPBUILDERS, &C., &C. All classes of engineering work and supply of stores undertaken. Pontoon Dock for raising vessels of the largest size.
BOULAC ENGINE WORKS
Branches at Sharia Bab-El-Hadeed (CAIRO), ALEXANDRIA AND KHARTOUM.
Sole agents in Egypt for
RICHARD GARRETT & SONS, LTD. Portable and semi-portable steam engines, Road rollers, threshing and straw-chopping machines.
SHAND, MASON & CO. Patent Steam and Manual Fire Engines.
NOBEL'S EXPLOSIVES CO., LTD. Gelignits, Blasting Gelatine, detonators, safety fuse, etc. ''Sporting Ballistite" and "Empire" Cartridges.
GEO. ANGUS & CO., LTD. Machine belting of every description, leather, rubber, cotton and Balata.
TANGYES LIMITED (SOLE VENDORS.) Steam, Oil and Gas Engines, with Produce Plants, Pumps and Machinery of all description.
CROMPTON & Co., LTD. Dynamos, motors and electric machinery of all description.
STOHWASSER & WINTER PUTTIE LEGGING & MILITARY EQUIPMENTS CORPORATION LTD. Agents for Jesse Ellis & Co. Steam and Oil Motor Wagons.
CHUBB & SON'S LOCK & SAFE CO. LTD Chubb's Steel Safes of all sizes on hand, the building of strong rooms undertaken.
COCHRAN & CO. ANNAN, LTD. The Cochran patent vertical boilers.
THE SEAMLESS STEEL BOAT CO., LTD. Seamless steel boats fitted with any class of motor.
THE COOPER STEAM DIGGER CO. LTD. Diggers made in size No. 5, 6, 8 and 12.
Specialities: TANGYES' GAS ENGINES with Producer Plants, COOPER PATENT STEAM DIGGER, specially suitable for small landowners.
Telegraphic Address :"ENGINEER, CAIRO" and "ENGINEER, ALEXANDRIA."
Works Office in town, Sharia Bab-El-Hadeed (Cairo).
Alexandria Office and Stores, Abu Dirdar Street, No. 12. 10.12.905

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark's Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906
